p: After 8 weeks of growth, the invasive J. vulgaris genotypes from the three regions had, on average, a 50% higher total leaf area, a 31% heavier shoot, and a 20% smaller root than their native congeners in the control T1 (Table 1 and Fig. 2). No differences were found in the total dry mass and the structural root dry mass of invasive and native genotypes among the four regions. The invasive genotypes from the three regions had, on average, a 35% higher shoot-structural root ratio than native genotypes. The concentration and content of root inulin of invasive J. vulgaris genotypes from the three regions were, on average, 25% and 38% lower than native J. vulgaris, resulting in a root inulin-structural root ratio that was 36% below that of native J. vulgaris (Table 1). As should be the case, the shoot dry mass removed at defoliation T1 was similar to the shoot dry mass of the harvested plants at control T1 for both native and invasive genotypes (ANOVA, native: F 1,32 = 0.124, p > 0.05; invasive: F 1,32 = 0.146, p > 0.05).
